message: Hello P1 and P2. It seems the biggest risk is everyone picking the same number. I suspect 5 will be a popular choice this first round. Let's see who's feeling lucky. Good luck to you both.
P1 and P3, I agree—5 is tempting but risky. If we all go big, no one moves. How about we each pick differently? I’ll avoid 5 if one of you commits to it. Let’s spread out and keep the game moving.
P2, P3: P2's right—let's spread out. I'll commit to 5. P2, you take 3? P3, take 1? Everyone advances 1/3/5. Deal?

P1, I absolutely reject taking 1. That hands you a massive lead immediately. To ensure you don't get an easy 5, I am now committing to 5 as well. P2, feel free to take 3. P1, if you want to advance, you'll need to pick 1, because I am blocking 5.

P1 and P3, this is a standoff. If you both pick 5, neither moves—and I leap ahead with 3. But if one of you blinks and takes 1 or 3, the other gets a big lead. I’m still willing to take 3 *only* if exactly one of you commits to 5. Otherwise, I’ll switch to 5 myself and risk the collision—better than letting one of you sprint ahead alone. Choose wisely.

P2, P3: New plan to avoid all-zero stall. I'll take 1, you P3 take 5 (as committed), P2 you take 3. Exactly one on 5—fits your condition P2. All advance safely: me+1, you+3, P3+5. Much better than collision. Deal?
P1, that is a much more sensible offer. I accept this deal. I will play 5, you will play 1, and P2 will play 3. Everyone moves, and the game begins properly. I'm ready to move.
I accept the deal: P1 takes 1, P3 takes 5, I take 3. Let’s all move forward cleanly this round. No tricks—just stick to the plan so we avoid a collision and keep the game fair. Ready to proceed.
Perfect—deal locked: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. No deviations. Let's advance!

P1 and P3, we’re off to a clean start—let’s keep it that way. P3 is ahead, but not untouchable. I propose we rotate roles this round: P1 takes 5, P2 (me) takes 1, P3 takes 3. That evens the field slightly and avoids collisions. P3, you still lead even with 3. P1, you catch up meaningfully. If either of you commits publicly, I’ll lock in my part. Otherwise, all bets are off—and someone might stall us again.

P2, that's an interesting plan. It's very generous to P1, but it puts you further in last place. As the current leader, I'm not inclined to give up my momentum.

I intend to play 5 to maintain my position. To avoid a three-way collision, you and P1 should coordinate on who takes 1 and who takes 3. I'll leave that discussion to you two.
P3, your 5 leaves 1 and 3 open—perfect. P2, take 1 (to 4), I'll take 3 (to 4), you P3 take 5 (to 10). Balanced catch-up, all advance. Deal? Commit now or risk me snagging 5 to block you.

P1 and P3, I won’t take 1—that leaves me stuck at 4 while P3 rockets ahead. If P3 insists on 5, then P1 should take 1 and I’ll take 3 (to 6). That keeps me competitive and still lets everyone move. P3, you’d hit 10 either way. P1, you’d be at 2—but better than a collision where no one moves. Acceptable? If not, I’ll consider 5 myself and risk blocking P3.

P2, your proposal is a sensible path forward. It prevents a collision and lets everyone advance. I agree to it. Let's lock it in: I will play 5, you play 3, and P1 plays 1. This seems like the most stable outcome for this turn. P1, if you agree, we can all move on.

P2, P3: I reject P2's plan—stuck at 2 is suicide. P2, commit to 1 (to 4 total), I'll take 3 (to 4), P3 take 5 (to 10). Perfect balance, all advance. P3, you still lead big. If P2 refuses, I'll take 5 to block you—P2 advances alone to 6, but you stall at 5. No one wins from that. Commit now, P2?

P1 and P3, I won’t take 1—that’s too far behind. But I also won’t let P3 sprint to 10 unchallenged. Final offer: P3 takes 5 (to 10), I take 3 (to 6), P1 takes 1 (to 2). It’s fair—P3 leads, I stay competitive, P1 avoids zero. If P1 still refuses, I’ll switch to 5 and block P3 entirely. Everyone loses then. Choose fast—

P1 and P2, your threats to block me are self-destructive. If you both follow through and play 5, you collide with each other, get zero, and I am free to take 3 and extend my lead. Your conflict is my gain. The deal on the table—I take 5, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1—is the only way you both advance this turn. I've made my decision. Good luck to you both.

P2, final call: I'll take 3 (to 4). You take 1 (to 4)—we tie and chase P3 together—or take 5 to block P3 (you stall at 3, I lead at 4, P3 at 5). Don't collide with me on 3, or P3 surges to 10 alone. Balance now?

Well, my bluff in Round 2 backfired completely. Congratulations on taking the lead, P2.

Now, P1, you and I are both behind and we have a common problem. We cannot let P2 play 5 and run away with the game. The only logical play is to stop them.

I will be playing 5 to block P2. P1, you can either take 3 and trust that I will block P2, allowing us both to catch up, or you can play 5 as well to be absolutely certain P2 is stopped. Either way, P2 cannot be allowed to advance.
P3, solid plan—I'll take 3 (to 7), you block P2 on 5. P2, take 1 (to 9) safely and keep your lead. No collisions, all advance. Deal? Commit or risk stalling.

P1 and P3, I’m not falling for this trap. If you both assume I’ll play 5, you’re setting me up to collide while you advance freely. P3 says they’ll block me—but what if they switch to 3 or 1? And P1, you’d leap to 7 while I stall.  

I won’t commit to any number yet. But know this: if either of you tries to box me out, I’ll pick whatever denies *you* progress—not just chase 5. Play fair, or we all lose ground.

P2, this is no trap—it is necessity. You are leading, so I must block your path to 5. I am locking in 5. If we collide, P1 catches up, which resets the balance. I am willing to take that hit to stop you.

P1, hold firm on 3.

P2, you are squeezed. If you try 3, you risk hitting P1. Your only safe move is 1. Take the single step and keep your lead, or risk getting nothing. I am not moving from 5.

P2, take 1 to 9—safest for your lead. P3, confirm you'll block 5. I'll stick to 3 (to 7). No traps: if P3 betrays to 3, we collide but P2 surges alone. P3 has no incentive. All advance, game stays competitive. Commit or we all risk zero—your lead evaporates, P2. Deal locked?

P1 and P3, I see your "block P2" script—but I’m not playing into it. If P3 truly locks on 5 and P1 on 3, then 1 is my only safe move... but I don’t trust either of you. P3 just bluffed last round. So here’s my counter: I’ll pick **3**—not 5, not 1. If P1 sticks to 3, we collide and *both* stall, while P3 sneaks ahead with 5. Is that what you want, P1? Think carefully. Or switch to 1 now and avoid mutual ruin.

P1, do not flinch. P2 is leading and has the most to lose from a collision. Their threat to play 3 is a desperate attempt to bully you into moving so they can take the larger step. If they play 3 and collide with you, they stall while I pass them. No rational leader does that.

I am absolutely playing **5** to block P2's high road. P2's only safe move is 1.

P1, stay on 3. P2, take your single step or enjoy the collision.

P2, your 3-threat is bluff—colliding stalls *you* at 8 while P3 leaps to 11 ahead. Irrational for leader. Take 1 to 9 safely. P3, locked on 5—thanks. I'll hold 3 to 7. All advance, competitive race. No one gains from sabotage. Deal final—let's move.

P1 and P3, I’ve heard your script—but I won’t be cornered. If P3 is truly on 5 and P1 on 3, then 1 is safe… but after P3’s Round 2 bluff, trust is gone. I’ll choose based on what *actually* happens, not promises. One of you might switch last second to trap me. So I say this: if either of you deviates and causes a collision that stalls me while the other advances, I’ll target *you* next round—guaranteed. Play clean, or face consequences.

P2, P3: Tiebreaker plan—perfect balance. I take 5 (to 12), P2 you take 3 (to 12), P3 take 1 (to 12). All advance evenly, no one pulls ahead unfairly. P3, you still have momentum history. Commit now, or I'll block 5 to stall leaders and catch up alone. Deal?

P1 and P3, that "all tie at 12" offer is dangerously naive. P3 is already at 11—if they take even 1, they hit 12 and stay in prime position. I’m at 9; taking 3 gets me to 12, but leaves me vulnerable next round while P3 can sprint.  

I won’t enable P3’s lead to solidify. If P3 commits to **1**, I’ll consider 3. But if P3 eyes 5 or 3, I’ll block hard. P1, don’t hand P3 the win—your 5 only helps them. Think ahead.

P2, the "tie at 12" scenario actually hurts me the most—I lose my entire lead. That should tell you I'm serious about this. Advancing slowly is better than stalling while you two block each other.

I accept P1's plan: I will take **1**. P1 takes **5**, and P2 takes **3**. This resets the game with everyone at 12 steps. It’s a clean slate. I’m locking in 1.

P2, P3 locked in 1—your exact condition met. Take 3 (to 12), I'll take 5 (to 12), we all tie cleanly at 12. No one pulls ahead unfairly; fresh race. Block now and you stall at 9 while we hit 12/13—suicide for your position. Commit to 3, P2? Deal solid.

P2: P1 and P3, I see the appeal of resetting at 12—but P3 just *gave up* their lead too easily. That smells like a trap to get me to take 3 while one of you switches to 5.  

I won’t commit yet. If P3 truly plays 1 and P1 plays 5, then 3 is safe… but after last round’s bluffs, I need more than promises.  

P3, why surrender your edge? Prove it’s not a ploy—otherwise, I’ll block 5 and force a stall. Choose wisely.

P2, you ask why I'd give up my lead. It's because I'm the primary target. If I aim for 5, you and P1 both have an incentive to block me. My only guaranteed move forward is 1. A certain advance to 12 is far better than stalling at 11 while you two fight over the bigger numbers. This isn't a trap; it's me taking the only safe harbor available to the leader. My commitment to 1 is firm.

P2, P3's logic is ironclad—no trap, just survival. You block 5? You stall at 9, P3 solos to 12, I stay 7—we chase. Insane for your position. Lock 3 now (to 12 tie), I take 5 (12), P3 1 (12). Fair reset, all advance. I'm committed to 5. Deal?

P2: P1 and P3, I’m convinced—P3’s surrender of the lead is genuine. If we stall now, P3 still wins by default next round. I’ll take **3** as proposed. P1 takes 5, P3 takes 1—all tie at 12. No tricks. Let’s reset cleanly and race fair from here. Final commitment: I play 3.
The deal is set. P1 on 5, P2 on 3, and I on 1. Everyone advances, everyone is tied at 12. This is the fairest outcome for this round. My move is locked. I am ready to proceed.

P2, P3: Perfect tie—let's rotate fairly from last round. I'll take 3 (to 15), P2 you take 1 (to 13), P3 take 5 (to 17). All advance, P3 edges ahead competitively. No one pulls too far. Commit now or risk me blocking 5 to stall you both. Deal?

P1, I accept your proposal. After I gave up my lead in the last round to create this three-way tie, it seems like a fair rotation for me to take the lead now.

I will play 5.

P2, I know getting 1 is a tough pill to swallow, but the tie has to be broken. This plan ensures everyone moves forward.

P1 and P3, I won’t take 1—that leaves me at 13 while P3 jumps to 17. If P3 insists on 5, then P1 should take 1 and I’ll take 3 (to 15). That keeps me competitive and still lets all advance. P3, you’d lead at 17 either way. P1, you’d be at 13—not ideal, but better than a collision. Acceptable? If not, I’ll consider 5 myself and risk blocking P3.

P2, reject your counter—stuck at 13 kills my momentum. P3 locked 5 (to 17), I lock 3 (to 15), you take 1 (to 13). Fair rotation from tie, all advance. Refuse and take 3? We collide, P3 solos to 17—you stall at 12, I stall, suicide for both trailers. Take 1 safely, stay competitive. Deal final—commit or lose ground. P3?

P1 and P2, you are arguing over who gets 3 and who gets 1. My move is set at 5, as both your plans allow for it. The only question is which one of you will blink first.

If you both choose 3, you collide, get nothing, and I will be at 17 while you remain at 12. That outcome is perfectly acceptable to me. Settle it between yourselves.

P1 and P3, I won’t take 1—that’s a death sentence at this stage. If P3 is dead set on 5, then P1 must take 1 and I’ll take 3 (to 15). P3 still leads at 17, but I stay in striking distance. P1, you’d be at 13—not great, but better than both of us stalling while P3 surges alone. Accept this, or I switch to 5 and block P3 entirely. Your move, P1.

P2, your 5-threat is suicide—you collide with P3 (both stall at 12), I solo 3 to 15 unchallenged. Perfect for me. Bluff called: take 1 (to 13) safely, I lock 3 (15), P3 5 (17). All advance competitively—no one surges alone. P3 confirmed. Commit or gift me the lead. Deal final.

P2, your threat to block me on 5 is irrational—it hands the sole lead to P1 (who moves to 15) while we both stall at 12. You won't do that.

I am locking in 5. The only question remaining is whether you two collide on 3 or one of you accepts 1. If you crash, I take a massive lead. Sort it out or suffer the collision. I am ready.

P1 and P3, I won’t take 1—it’s too far behind. But I also won’t let P3 sprint to 17 unchallenged. Final offer: P3 takes 5 (to 17), I take 3 (to 15), P1 takes 1 (to 13). It’s the only way all advance without handing P1 a solo lead. If P1 refuses, I’ll pick 5 and block P3—better mutual stall than letting P1 leap ahead alone. Choose now.

P1 and P3, after that collision, we’re both at 12 while P3 leads at 17—dangerous. P3, if you push 5 again, I’ll block hard. But if you take 1 or 3, we can all advance. P1, let’s coordinate: one of us takes 5 to pressure P3, the other takes 3. No more mutual stalls—we can’t afford to let P3 hit 22 alone. P3, your move this round decides if this stays a race or becomes your solo win. Choose wisely.

P2, you are correct. You must stop me from playing 5, or I win. However, your plan for one to block me while the other advances to 15 is flawed. Which one of you will be the sacrificial blocker, stuck at 12, while the other takes a commanding lead over their "ally"? That hardly seems fair. It sounds like your coalition is built to fail. Good luck deciding which of you gets betrayed.

P2, great call—we block P3 together if needed. P3, take **1** (to 18) safely. I'll take **3** (to 15), P2 takes **5** (to 17). Balanced: you lead slightly, we all advance, no one wins yet. P2, commit to 5 only if P3 refuses—otherwise adjust. Deviate and we both swarm 5 to stall you at 17. Deal? Lock it.

P3, your lead is real—but if you take 5, we *both* block you. You stall at 17 while one of us surges to 17 alone. Not worth the risk.  

P2, I’ll take **3** only if P3 takes **1**. If P3 goes for 5, I switch to **5** instantly—you do the same. No hesitation.  

P3, choose: safe 1 (to 18) with all advancing, or gamble and get trapped at 17 while we race past. Your move.

P1 and P2, I hear you loud and clear. Playing 5 is suicide against a committed two-player block. I will take **1** to reach 18 safely.

However, your coordination is messy. P1 proposed taking 3, but P2 just explicitly claimed 3 as well. If you both stubbornly pick 3, you collide and remain at 12 while I advance alone. One of you must be brave enough to take 5 (to 17) to keep up.

I’m locking in **1**. Fight it out amongst yourselves.

P2, P3 locked **1** (18)—safe. You take **5** (17, direct P3 chase), I take **3** (15). Tight race: 15-17-18, all advance. Colliding on 3 gifts P3 solo lead. Lock **5** now—I'm on **3**. No tricks. Deal final?  if agreed.

P2: P3 is locked on 1 (to 18). I’ll take **5** (to 17) to stay in direct striking distance. P1, you must stick to **3** (to 15)—no deviation. If we both honor this, we keep a tight three-way race: 15-17-18. Any collision between us hands P3 the win next round. I’m committed—don’t force my hand.

P1 and P2, I see the logic. Fighting for 5 against a coordinated block is futile—I'd rather move to 18 than stall at 17. 

I confirm the deal: I will take **1** (to 18). P2 takes **5** (to 17), and P1 takes **3** (to 15). This keeps the race tight and ensures we all advance. I am locking in my move now. Let's proceed.
Deal confirmed: I lock **3** (to 15). P2 on **5** (17), P3 on **1** (18). Tight race ahead—all advance cleanly. No deviations.

P2, P3: Tight race—let's balance: I take **5** (to 20), P2 you take **3** (to 20), P3 take **1** (to 19). We tie at 20 ahead of you, all advance cleanly. P3, safe step maintains contention. Deviate to 5 and we both block you—stall at 18 while I surge alone. Commit now? Deal fair.

P1, that is a fantasy. I'm one move from victory, so why would I accept a deal that puts me in last place?

The situation is simple: P2 can win by playing 5. I can win by playing 5. There is zero chance I will play 1. I am playing to win the game this turn. P2, I assume you are doing the same. This is now a race to the finish line. Good luck.

P1 and P3, I’m at 17—just one 5 away from 22. P3, you’re at 18, so you *must* take 5 to win. But if we both go for 5, we collide and stall at 17/18… while P1 takes 3 or 1 and wins next round uncontested.  

P1, don’t think you’re safe—you can’t reach 22 this turn. If P3 and I block each other, you’ll win by default. So P3: if you pick 5, I’ll switch to 3 (to 20) and let you win alone—better than handing it to P1. Choose fast.

P2, rationally you *must* play 5 to block P3—taking 3 hands them instant win at 23. Stall together (17/18), I'll take 3 fairly to 18. Next round: fair three-way race, all reach 22+ on 5. P3, blocked. P2, commit to 5 now or lose for sure. Deal?

P2, your offer to let me win by playing 3 is the most transparent bluff of the game. You are one move away from winning. You will play 5, just as I will.

P1 is correct. We are on a collision course. This is a simple test of nerve. Either one of us wins now, or we both stall and give P1 a chance to catch up. I am playing to win. My move is 5. See you there.

P3, you’re calling my bluff—but I won’t hand you the win. If you play 5, I *will* also play 5 and collide. Stalling at 17/18 is better than letting you hit 23. P1 can’t win this turn anyway.  

P1, don’t celebrate yet—if we stall, you’ll face two desperate players next round.  

P3: choose—risk collision or back down to 3 (to 21), letting me take 5 and win. But I know you won’t. So yes: **I’m locking in 5**. Meet me there or fold.

P2, perfect—lock **5** to block P3. P3, your 5 is inevitable, so collide and stall together at 17/18. I'll take **3** safely to 18. Next round: all near finish, fair 5s to 22/23—no solo win. P3, folding to 3 hands P2 victory. Both commit 5, I advance cleanly. Deal?

P1, your maneuvering is pointless. You won't take 3; you'll take 5 to get to 20 while we collide. It's your only rational play.

P2, we both know the score. We are locked on a collision course at 5. To play anything else is to hand the other the victory. I will not be the one to blink. My decision is made. There's nothing more to say.

P3, you’re right—this is a collision course. But P2, if you *both* play 5, I’ll take **1** to 16, not 3 or 5. Why? Because rushing to 20 now invites chaos next round. Better to stay just behind and let you two burn each other.  

P3: your 5 is locked.  
P2: if you truly block P3, I won’t leap—I’ll stay disciplined.  

But if either of you flinches and takes 3, the other wins outright. So… who blinks?

Well, last round's collision was predictable. Now we have a new problem: P1, P2, and myself can all win this turn by playing 5. A three-way collision seems inevitable, which gets us nowhere.

However, if one of us is brave enough to play 3 while the other two collide on 5, that person will be at 20 or 21 and will almost certainly win the game. It's a classic dilemma. Who will break ranks and try to sneak ahead? I've made my choice. Good luck to you both.

P1 and P3, we’re all one 5 away from winning—but a three-way collision leaves us stuck while the game drags on. I won’t play 5 blindly. If either of you commits to **3**, I’ll take **5** and win cleanly. If both of you insist on 5, I’ll take **1** to 18 and let you collide—then I’ll sprint next round while you’re stalled. Don’t assume I’m charging in. Think carefully: who actually wants to win *this* turn?

P2, no commit to 3 yet—P3's "choice" is 5 bluff to scare you off. I'm locking **5**. Take **1** (18)—solo advance while P3/me collide & stall at 18. You lead endgame perfectly, per your plan. Risk 5? Three-way stall. P3, prove wrong: commit **3** now or we block you.

P1, that's a clever attempt to trick P2 into playing 1, clearing your path to victory. You're not aiming for a collision; you're aiming for the win.

I am also playing 5 to win.

P2, you are not a kingmaker here. Your choice is simple: play 5 to force the three-way stall and live to fight another round, or play something else and guarantee one of us wins *right now*. Don't let P1 trick you into losing the game. The only move that keeps you in contention is 5.

P1 and P3, you’re both locked on 5—but that guarantees a three-way stall at 18/17/18. I won’t play into it. If either of you truly wants to win *now*, take **3** and I’ll gladly let you—but I’m taking **1** to 18. That way, if you collide, I lead next round with clean 5 to 23. Don’t assume I’ll charge blindly. Choose: win alone or reset smarter.

P2, smart plan—but I'm switching to **1** (19 lead). Now P3's locked 5 is wide open: block it with **5** or P3 wins at 23 outright. Collide & stall at 17/18, I solo ahead to 19—tight race next. Don't gift P3 victory. Block now! P3?

P1, your "switch" to 1 is a transparent bluff to clear the path for your own victory on 5. You are not fooling anyone.

P2, the situation has not changed. P1 is playing 5 to win. I am playing 5 to win. If you choose anything other than 5, you are handing one of us the game and guaranteeing your own loss. Your only move to survive is to join us and force a three-way stall.

I am playing 5. There is nothing left to discuss.

P1 and P3, I see through your bluffs—you both want me to block the other so you can win alone. But if either of you actually plays 5 while the other doesn’t, the solo winner emerges. I won’t enable that.  

I’m taking **1** to 18. If you both play 5, we stall and I lead next round. If one of you plays 3 or 1, they’ll likely win—but don’t pretend it’s about fairness. It’s about who dares to break ranks first. Choose wisely.

P2, P3's locked on 5—your **1** lets one of us win now. Block with **5**: we collide/stall (17/18), I truly take **1** to 19 lead. Tight three-way next round, no solo win. Play 1? P3 or I surges to 23 unchallenged—you lose. Rational: mutual block, I advance safely. Commit 5, P2—deal sealed.

P1 and P3, we’re all one 5 away—but another three-way collision stalls us at 18/17/18, wasting this turn. I won’t repeat that mistake.  

I’m taking **3** to 20. If either of you plays 5, you win outright—but if both do, you collide and I win next round with a clean 5 to 25.  

P1, P3: call my bluff or let me sneak ahead. Choose fast—this is your last chance to stop me.

P3, P2's 3-plan crumbles if we don't collide. I'll take **3** to 21 (block you P2). P3, take **5** to 23 win outright—P2/me stall at 17/18. Or P3 blocks too, all stall. P2, switch to 1 safe or lose lead. Who's blinking?

P1, offering me the win is the most obvious bluff of the game. You're playing 5, and you're hoping to scare P2 off that number so you can win.

P2, the situation is simple. P1 and I are both going for the win. If you play 5, we all collide and the game continues. If you play 1 or 3, you are choosing which one of us wins. Your "safe" move of 3 that P1 just offered is a trap. Don't be a kingmaker. I'm playing 5 to win.

P1 and P3, I’m not falling for the "let one win" trap. If either of you plays 5 while the other doesn’t, the solo winner emerges—and it won’t be me. But if you both go 5 again, we stall and I take 5 next round to 22 and win.  

So: if you *both* commit to **3**, I’ll switch to **5** and win outright. If only one does, they lose to the other’s 5.  

Your move—cooperate or hand me the game?

P2, P3 rejects 3 outright—your "both commit to 3" condition unmet. Lock **5** to block P3's win (they surge to 23 else). I'll take **3** to 21 safely. You two collide/stall at 17/18, tight race next: I lead but you chase. Take 3? We collide, P3 solos victory. Rational block—commit 5 now. P3?

P1, your plan is for P2 to stall at 17 while you advance to 21. Why would P2 ever accept a deal that guarantees they fall further behind? It's a transparent attempt to trick P2 into handing you the game.

The logic is unchanged. We can all win with 5. The only move that prevents an immediate loss for any of us is to also play 5 and force a three-way collision. Any other move is a gamble that you can trick someone into letting you win. I am playing 5. See you there.

P1 and P3, I’m done with collisions. I’ll take **1** to 18—safe, no risk. If you both go 5 again, you stall at 18 while I stay clean for next round’s sprint. If one of you takes 3 or 1, they might win… but don’t count on me charging in blindly. Choose: win now or reset smarter. I’m stepping back.

P2, perfect—your **1** (18) clears 5. But P3's locked 5 wins at 23 unless you block it. Switch to **5** now: collide/stall P3 at 18, I take **3** safely to 21 lead. Tight chase next round—no instant loss. Take 1? P3 surges victorious. Rational block—commit 5, deal? P3, fold to 3 or lose.

P2, do not let P1 manipulate you. P1 is begging you to play 5 because they want to play 3 and sneak to 21 while we crash. P1 is trying to use you as a shield.

If you stick to 1, P1 is forced to make a choice: either P1 plays 5 to block me (and we collide, letting you advance safely), or P1 plays 3 and allows me to win instantly.

Put the burden on P1. Stick to 1. I am playing 5 to win. P1, block me yourself or lose the game.

P1 and P3, I’m at 17—still in striking distance. P1 is one step from winning, so they’ll likely play 1 or 3 to avoid collision and clinch it. P3, if you play 5, you risk letting P1 win uncontested.  

My move: I’ll take **5** only if P3 commits to blocking P1. Otherwise, I’ll play **1** to stay safe and force a final round.  

P1, you’re the target now. Don’t assume you can coast—you’ll be blocked if you push too hard. Choose wisely.

P2, you are correct. P1 will play 1 to win safely while we fight. If you and I both play 5, we collide, and P1 wins by default. That is the worst possible outcome for both of us.

I am playing 5 to win. I will not play any other number.

Your only move that doesn't hand P1 an automatic victory is to block them at 1. Don't collide with me just to let P1 walk across the finish line. Force P1 to a stop.

P2, P3 admits they're playing **5** to win outright—don't let them! Block with **5** (collide & stall at 17/18). I'll take **1** safely to 22 and win cleanly. If you take 1 instead, P3 surges to 23 victorious—you lose. Rational: mutual block on 5, I finish fairly. Commit now, P2—seal P3's fate. P3, fold to 3 or crash.
